title: Retail Property Management Enters Its Next Phase: Integrated, Experiential And Connected
snippet: Retail property management has evolved. What was once about shopping is now about curating experiences. Find out what this looks like in practice.
content: Retail Property Management Enters Its Next Phase: Integrated, Experiential And Connected SUBSCRIBE Cities Atlanta Austin - San Antonio Baltimore Boston Charlotte Chicago Dallas-Fort Worth Denver Dublin Houston London Los Angeles New York Oakland Philadelphia Phoenix Raleigh/Durham San Francisco San Jose South Florida Washington, D.C. Events Calendar Educational Workshops First Draft Live Elevate Ascent Escape Apply to Speak Sponsor an Event Careers Top Talent Employer SelectLeaders Bisnow Careers Press Releases Subscriptions Newsletters Newsletter Archive Insider Access Newsletters Insider Access Archives About Contact Us Advertise with Us Newsletters Careers Home Choose your city National Atlanta Austin - San Antonio Baltimore Boston Charlotte Chicago Dallas-Fort Worth Denver Dublin Houston London Los Angeles New York Oakland Philadelphia Phoenix Raleigh/Durham San Francisco San Jose South Florida Washington, D.C. Cities Events Calendar Educational Workshops First Draft Live Elevate Ascent Escape Apply to Speak Sponsor an Event Careers Top Talent Employer SelectLeaders Bisnow Careers Press Releases Subscriptions Newsletters Newsletter Archive Insider Access Newsletters Insider Access Archives About Contact Us Advertise with Us Careers Contact Us My Subscriptions Newsletters Newsletter Archives Insider Access Newsletters Insider Access Archives My Purchases Tickets Attendee Lists Videos Invoices Edit Profile Log Out GO Login Sign Up GO United States News New York Real Estate News Contact Us Edit Story Bisnow Content Partner: Cushman & Wakefield www.cushmanwakefield.com Sponsored Content Retail Property Management Enters Its Next Phase: Integrated, Experiential And Connected New York Retail View count: New York Retail November 24, 2025 | 12:21 p.m. ET Cushman & Wakefield Julia Troy, Studio B Editor Unsplash/Victor Bystrov Retail property management isn’t what it used to be. The business has evolved from maintaining buildings and collecting rent to curating experiences, building communities and creating environments where people want to stay longer and come back often. This is the new reality of retail that Evan Walke , Cushman & Wakefield's managing director and national retail lead for its Asset Services group, is seeing. Walke said this evolution is accelerating as mixed-use developments combine retail, multifamily, office and entertainment into a single, dynamic ecosystem. “At Cushman & Wakefield, we’re seeing firsthand how these changes are reshaping what clients expect from their property management teams and how our approach is adapting to meet that moment,” he said. From Managing Space to Managing Experience Traditional retail property management was largely transactional: Keep the lights on, collect the rent and manage maintenance. Today, retail is increasingly experiential. Shoppers expect activation and engagement, from pop-up markets and public art to digital touchpoints that extend beyond the walls of the property. “For property managers, that means shifting from operational oversight to experience orchestration,” Walke said. “Every decision, from how common areas are programmed to how tenants are supported on the marketing front, helps define the overall brand of the property.” That’s why Cushman & Wakefield created a dedicated Asset Services group. The goal is to bring specialized expertise to an asset class that requires a distinct operational mindset. “Retail is public-facing, fast-moving, and deeply dependent on the success of its tenants,” he said. “The work doesn’t end when a lease is signed – it begins. Helping tenants open faster, perform better and stay connected with customers is now a core part of the job.” The New Shape of Retail: Mixed-Use and Reimagined Malls Across the country, traditional malls and suburban shopping centers are being reinvented. Owners are transforming underperforming assets into vibrant mixed-use communities that bring shopping, dining, living and working together in one connected

title: Studio to Street – Alo Yoga Shoes That Support Every Step
snippet: The Alo Yoga collection of shoes is where mindful movement meets everyday style – a smartly designed collection that is crafted both in the studio and on the street. Regardless of whether it’s exercise or just going out to grab a coffee,
content: Studio to Street - Alo Yoga Shoes That Support Every Step - GigWise Skip to content Pinterest Instagram Facebook-f X-twitter Linkedin Search Trending Today Hot Topics Music & Artists Singers and Vocalists Bands and Musical Groups Celebrity Analysis and Profiles Celebrity Wealth & Finance Business Ventures Legacy Profiles Luxury Cars Luxury Real Estate Home Renovations Real Estate Investments Construction & Plumbing Health & Wellness Healthy Recipes Fitness Routines Healthy Eating Weight Management VIP Lifestyles Beauty & Makeup Fashion Trends and Advice Personal Development Wedding Dresses & Attire Wedding Planning & Gifts Lifestyle and Self-Care Exclusive Household Tips Home Improvements Moving & Relocation Furniture Gardening Home and Living Music & Artists Singers and Vocalists Bands and Musical Groups Celebrity Analysis and Profiles Celebrity Wealth & Finance Business Ventures Legacy Profiles Luxury Cars Luxury Real Estate Home Renovations Real Estate Investments Construction & Plumbing Health & Wellness Healthy Recipes Fitness Routines Healthy Eating Weight Management VIP Lifestyles Beauty & Makeup Fashion Trends and Advice Personal Development Wedding Dresses & Attire Wedding Planning & Gifts Lifestyle and Self-Care Exclusive Household Tips Home Improvements Moving & Relocation Furniture Gardening Home and Living Search Fashion Trends and Advice Studio to Street – Alo Yoga Shoes That Support Every Step By Mia Robertson Published on November 22, 2025 10:45 am The moment is here! Alo Yoga’s Black Friday celebration runs from November 24th to 27th. Enjoy an incredible 30% OFF everything sitewide all weekend long. Don’t wait— join now to shop ! The Alo Yoga collection of shoes is where mindful movement meets everyday style – a smartly designed collection that is crafted both in the studio and on the street. Regardless of whether it’s exercise or just going out to grab a coffee, each pair will be designed to support, cushion, and elevate . The Recovery Mode Sneaker is one of the most impressive models created by Alo, which is based on wellness and recovery. It features a high-rebound foam insole, designed to support the pressure points of the feet, ankles, and even knees. To have a more stylish and trendy version, the Sunset Sneaker is an excellent choice of a shoe with both retro and comfort feel. Sneakers are not the end of Alo, with their It Slide and Sherpa Recovery Slipper, they bring the same focus on comfort to the loungewear footwear. In every type, Alo Yoga is shoes that combine a mindful fusion of functionality and style: reliable support and recovery, responsible materials, and a high aesthetic that supplements the brand’s activewear. When you are walking or taking a break, these shoes will make you feel purposeful at every step. What puts Alo Yoga at the forefront of transforming contemporary culture, fashion, and wellness Studio-to-Street Versatility The main philosophy of Alo is mindful movement, and it is reflected in designs that will perform both on the mat and in real life. Smooth leggings and ribbed tops, sculpting fabric such as Airbrush, and Alosoft are not only functional but will be fashionable enough to wear to brunch, work, or travel. A Healthy Wellness Ecosystem. It is not only that Alo is selling clothes, but also creating a wellness community. They do not only create clothing: they run yoga, a digital studio, and mindfulness content. This promise makes the customers perceive Alo as a lifestyle rather than a health wear brand. Sustainability & Ethics to the Core. Alo has a unique opportunity to express its sustainability because, in an ever-conscious world regarding the impact of fast fashion and its effect on the environment, Alo has positioned itself as a company that values its sustainability. They use recycled fabrics and produce in sweatshop-free plants, and they focus on ethical production. Their LA headquarters is solar-powered. This makes Alo a brand that members of the conscious consumer gr

title: How Baton Rouge store owners are adapting to a shifting retail landscape
snippet: Local boutiques are adapting to a retail landscape reshaped by crises and shifting consumer behavior, 225 writes. Hemline Towne Center owner Muffy LeBlanc—who relocated from New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina—says the hurricane’s lessons helped her weather COVID,

GET DAILY REPORT FREE Baton Rouge Business Report BECOME AN INSIDER LOGIN Data Business Politics Opinions Real Estate Newsletters Daily Report AM Daily Report PM 10/12 Industry Weekly Sign up for our free newsletters Guides Capital Region 500 2024 StartUp City 2025 Welcome: Official Visitor’s Guide to Greater Baton Rouge Business Lunch Directory Corporate Media Workplaces that Work Local Legacies Real Estate Roundtable What’s New in Health Care Annual Report Mission BR Be Our Guest Cancer Connection Giving Guide Events BECOME AN INSIDER LOGIN GET DAILY REPORT FREE BECOME AN INSIDER LOGIN Home Newsletters Daily Report AM How Baton Rouge store owners are adapting to a shifting retail landscape Wednesday, November 19, 2025 How Baton Rouge store owners are adapting to a shifting retail landscape By Daily Report Staff - November 19, 2025 Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Print Local boutiques are adapting to a retail landscape reshaped by crises and shifting consumer behavior, 225 writes . Hemline Towne Center owner Muffy LeBlanc—who relocated from New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina—says the hurricane’s lessons helped her weather COVID, which pushed boutiques to rapidly build online sales and social media strategies. Today, retailers like H Kyle Boutique rely almost entirely on digital operations, leaning into authentic, personality-driven content that resonates more than traditional photo shoots. Despite competition from Amazon and big-box chains, owners say personal service, trust and community relationships keep independent stores relevant. Carriages Fine Clothier notes Baton Rouge’s event-driven fashion culture continues to support menswear sales. Looking ahead, boutique owners see trends cycling back—retro looks, prints and cleaner, less logo-heavy styles. Read the full story.
